title: Enable Aviator
content:
To use this capability, you need the ITOM Aviator license.

After the Aviator capability is added to the tenant, the tenant admin needs to complete the following tasks to enable Aviator.

Index external knowledge

This task is required only if you want to feed external knowledge to Aviator. For more information about how to do it, see Index external knowledge using IDOL connectors.

Enable smart virtual agent

  1. Sign in to the agent interface.
  2. From the main menu, choose Administration > Configuration > Application Settings. 
  3. Locate the Enable smart virtual agent option, set it to On, and then click Save.

Enable the Aviator mode

  1. From the main menu, choose Administration > Configuration > AI Studio > Virtual Agent and click the Configurations tab.
  2. In the Virtual agent setting section, set Mode to Aviator.
  3. To update other fields in this section, refer to Configure Aviator.
  4. Click Save.

Note: If you're using intents, go to the Intents tab and train the intents in both the Classic mode and Aviator mode to avoid missing intents when switching between modes. The Train button becomes active only when there are three or more enabled intents.

Assign the Access Aviator permission to a role

Tenant admins have the Access Aviator permission by default. As a tenant admin, you can assign the Access Aviator permission to a role, allowing a specific group of users to use the Aviator capability. Users will be interacting with the classic virtual agent if they don't have this permission assigned.

  1. From the main menu, choose Administration > Master Data > People > Roles.
  2. Select the required role, locate the Aviator section, and then select the Access Aviator checkbox.
    If your users need to access Aviator from Agent Interface and the Agent interface inherits self-service role permissionssetting is disabled, you need to select the Log into the application permission for the same role.
  3. On the top of the page, click Save.

Aviator limitations in cross-domain integration scenarios

The following limitations apply to Aviator users in cross-domain integration scenarios. An example of cross-domain integration scenario is when your Suite deployment is integrated with other products such as AI Operations Management (AIOM) or Universal Discovery and CMDB (UD/UCMDB) for information exchange.

  • If you open Aviator in a private browsing mode, such as Incognito in Chrome, it may not return any responses to your requests.

  • While using Aviator, if the session times out, you may be asked to log in again.
